item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of PCBs
item.description:
Following the restoration of the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms on a Beogram 4002 turntable, the subsequent task involves refurbishing the printed circuit boards (PCBs) and replacing the reservoir capacitor. The initial focus is on the main PCB. It was in its original state, showing signs of age and use. A detailed view highlights the RPM control section, which was particularly important for speed stability. All electrolytic capacitors on the board were replaced with new, high-quality Japanese components rated for 105 degrees Celsius...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-restoration-of-pcbs/

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Main and Power Supply PCBs
item.description:
Following the replacement of the reservoir and motor capacitors on the Beogram 4000, the next stage was to focus on the main and power supply PCBs. It’s recommended to replace the RPM relay and trimmers alongside the electrolytic capacitors due to their susceptibility to corrosion. The main PCB in its original state can be seen here: A closer look at the outdated Siemens relay and RPM trimmers: And the outcome after component replacement:..
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4000-restoration-of-the-main-and-power-supply-pcbs/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the PCBs
item.description:
Following the repair of the Beogram 4002 (5513)’s arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, the next stage of restoration involved the electronics and platter drive. As usual, the process commenced with the replacement of all electrolytic capacitors on the printed circuit boards (PCBs) with new, high-quality Japanese capacitors rated for 105 degrees Celsius. To ensure the DC motor operates smoothly and without speed variations, the RPM relay was upgraded to a modern, enclosed unit, and 25-turn precision trimmers were installed for precise RPM adjustment...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-rebuilding-the-pcbs/

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing all Electrolytic Capacitors and the RPM Relay
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, a humming sound and vibration from the solenoid were traced back to a faulty 30V power supply. The reservoir capacitance was depleted, causing instability in the solenoid’s power supply and preventing the arm lowering mechanism from functioning correctly. To address this, the reservoir and motor capacitors were rebuilt. A custom-designed 3D printed part was used to house the new capacitors, ensuring a secure fit within the original capacitor bay...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4000-replacing-all-electrolytic-capacitors-and-the-rpm-relay/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of PCBs and RPM Adjustment Panel
item.description:
Some time ago, I refurbished a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor for a client in California. However, even after the motor was reinstalled, the turntable still exhibited noticeable speed variations at 45 RPM. This often indicates a problem with the RPM relay, specifically oxidation. These relays tend to fail at 45 RPM first because most Beograms are typically used at 33 RPM, leaving the 45 RPM contacts unused and prone to oxide buildup...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-restoration-of-pcbs-and-rpm-adjustment-panel/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): Too Early Arm Lowering and RPM Change During START
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 (5524) turntables I’ve been repairing had a recurring issue: during the start-up sequence, the arm wouldn’t consistently lower at the 30 cm mark. Occasionally, the RPM would unexpectedly switch to 45 right after pressing start. Troubleshooting was challenging because the problem was intermittent. I replaced all the electrolytic capacitors, the RPM relay, and trimmers, as detailed on my blog. To test, I installed the boards in my own Beogram 4002 (5513)...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5524-too-early-arm-lowering-and-rpm-change-during-start/

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning the Switches
item.description:
A significant issue with the Beogram 4000 design lies in its numerous exposed mechanical switches. Many usability problems stem from oxidized or bent contact tabs on these switches. Attempts to fix these issues often involve bending the contact tabs, which can worsen the problem. This was true for the Beogram I’m currently restoring. After replacing the solenoid, the right slide transfer button malfunctioned. While replacing the control panel’s light bulbs with SMD LEDs, I also cleaned the switch contacts...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4000-cleaning-the-switches/

item.title: Beogram 4002: Awesome Refurbished Keypads in the House!
item.description:
I received two refurbished Beogram 4002 keypads from Denmark today. My friend, who did the repainting, said the weather conditions were perfect for the job, and he was right! The picture shows how fantastic they look. He’s incredibly talented! The keypads look brand new, as if they were just made in 1975. He did a phenomenal job. I had sent him a worn-out keypad from a Beogram 4002 I recently restored, and he even found another one!..
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-awesome-refurbished-keypads-in-the-house-/

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the PCBs
item.description:
Following the control cluster restoration of a Beogram 4000, attention turned to the PCBs. The main PCB was initially in average condition. The standard procedure involves replacing all electrolytic capacitors with high-quality Japanese equivalents, installing a new RPM relay, and substituting the original single-turn RPM adjustment trimmers with 25-turn encapsulated ones for increased precision. Capacitor replacement is critical as aging and potential leakage can lead to operational issues. The RPM section, shown below, exemplifies this...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4000-restoration-of-the-pcbs/

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the PCBs and the AC Platter Motor
item.description:
Following the refurbishment of the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms on the Beogram 4000, the next stage was to substitute the electrolytic capacitors, the RPM control relay and trimmers, and the AC platter motor. The initial setup, including the original reservoir, motor capacitor, and AC platter motor, was documented before removal. After removing the existing components, new capacitors were installed in a custom-designed 3D printed holder, designed to fit the original strap...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4000-restoration-of-the-pcbs-and-the-ac-platter-motor/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): Rebuilding the Main and Output PCBs
item.description:
I recently got the main circuit board, output circuit board, and DC motor from a Beogram 4002 (5524) turntable. A customer in the UK sent them to me to fix because the platter’s RPM wasn’t consistent and the arm wouldn’t lower to the correct position when starting. My usual process for these is to replace the electrolytic capacitors, install a new relay, and swap the single-turn RPM adjustment knobs with 25-turn ones for more precise control...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5524-rebuilding-the-main-and-output-pcbs/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Further Improvement of the RPM Stability Through Replacement of the RPM Trimmers and the RPM Relay
item.description:
Following the DC motor rebuild, which significantly enhanced the RPM stability of the Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration project, the main RPM trimmers and relay were replaced. It was hoped this would further improve RPM stability and bring the Beogram back to the 0.05% specification outlined in the service manual. While accessing the main PCB, all electrolytic capacitors were exchanged with high-quality, 105C grade Japanese-manufactured equivalents. The board’s original and upgraded conditions are pictured...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-further-improvement-of-the-rpm-stability-through-replacement-of-the-rpm-trimmers-and-the-rpm-relay/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacing all Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description:
Following the repair of a peculiar control system problem, I proceeded with the comprehensive restoration process. This involved replacing all electrolytic capacitors, a crucial step given their tendency to dry out in these units. Notably, Ta type capacitors can become a fire hazard upon failure, making the upgrade to modern Aluminum 105C types a wise decision. The main PCB in its original state is depicted here: And here it is after capacitor replacement:..
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5501-replacing-all-electrolytic-capacitors/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Replacing all Electrolytic Capacitors and Rebuilding of the Platter RPM Control System
item.description:
During the electronic restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5514) turntable, the electrolytic capacitors were replaced and new relays were installed to enhance RPM stability. The aging tantalum capacitors, known for their tendency to fail catastrophically, were replaced as a precautionary measure. The main board was refurbished, replacing the electrolytic capacitors and installing new relays, including a custom-designed replacement for the Siemens relay that ensures precise RPM control. The original reservoir capacitor, a dual-capacitor unit no longer in production, was replaced with a 3D-printed fixture housing two modern capacitors...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5514-replacing-all-electrolytic-capacitors-and-rebuilding-of-the-platter-rpm-control-system/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Rebuilding the Control System and RPM Stability Qualification with the BeoloverRPM Device
item.description:
After addressing the fundamental components, such as the tracking system and platter motor, in the Beogram 4002 (5523) restoration project, I turned my attention to enhancing the electronic control system. This involved replacing electrolytic capacitors, baseline RPM trimmers, and the RPM and output relays. Additionally, I incorporated a grounding switch to connect system and signal grounds, a measure often effective in mitigating ground loop/humming problems. Here are some noteworthy observations:..
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5523-rebuilding-the-control-system-and-rpm-stability-qualification-with-the-beoloverrpm-device/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of PCBs and Reservoir Capacitors
item.description:
Following the refurbishment of the tonearm and drive carriage mechanisms on this Beogram 4002 (5513), attention turned to the electronics. The initial phase involved replacing all electrolytic capacitors, RPM trimmers, and the relay to guarantee smooth operation for years to come. The main PCB in its original state is shown here. The same PCB is pictured here after component replacement. This image provides a detailed view of the RPM control section...

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Exchanging all Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description:
After finishing most of the mechanical work, it was time to start repairing the electronics on a Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable. Replacing all electrolytic capacitors is recommended, as their internal fluid often leaks or dries up. I use high-quality Japanese capacitors to ensure my repairs last as long as possible. Tantalum capacitors, in particular, must be replaced because they can fail dramatically if a short circuit occurs, potentially damaging the circuit board...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5503-exchanging-all-electrolytic-capacitors/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Electrolytic Capacitors, RPM Relay and Trimmers on the Main PCB
item.description:
Following the DC motor rebuild on this Beogram 4002 (5513), the main PCB was addressed. All electrolytic capacitors were swapped with high-quality, Japanese-made, 105C-rated capacitors. The existing Tantalum capacitors, known for their tendency to fail dramatically, were preemptively replaced with modern equivalents to avoid any potential issues. Images illustrate the original board and the sections targeted for capacitor replacement. The author designed a replacement for the original Siemens relay using a modern, fully encapsulated SMD relay...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-replacing-the-electrolytic-capacitors-rpm-relay-and-trimmers-on-the-main-pcb/

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the PCBs - New Capacitors, RPM Trimmers and RPM Relay
item.description:
Following the replacement of the motor and reservoir capacitors in the Beogram 4000 restoration, the next step involved rebuilding the PCBs. This typically involves replacing all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM trimmers, and the RPM relay. The main PCB, which is difficult to remove due to its hardwiring, was ‘flipped’ for component replacement. After replacing the components, the rebuilt board was ready for installation. A new relay was used, as the original Siemens relays often experience oxidation, hindering proper RPM switching...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4000-restoration-of-the-pcbs-new-capacitors-rpm-trimmers-and-rpm-relay/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the PCBs and Restoring the 33 RPM Function
item.description:
Typically, my restoration process for Beogram 4002 turntables begins with the arm lowering and tracking systems. However, this particular Beogram 4002 (5513) required a different approach. The control system needed attention, so I opted to address the PCBs first. Upon unpacking the turntable, I discovered that the platter motor would power on as soon as it was plugged in. This unusual behavior was caused by the seller connecting the motor to the standby LED header on the circuit board â€“ a connection point rarely used on the 5513 boards...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-rebuilding-the-pcbs-and-restoring-the-33-rpm-function/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoration of Main and Output Printed Circuit Boards, and a New Reservoir Capacitor
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 (5523) restoration continued with a focus on the PCBs after addressing the decayed transport lock bushings. The main PCB was first, as shown below: In addition to replacing all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM relay and trimmers were targeted due to their susceptibility to corrosion and impact on RPM stability. The following image highlights the RPM section in its initial condition: Modern, encapsulated 25-turn trimmers replaced the old ones, and a new relay was installed (interested enthusiasts can obtain a replacement relay by email or through the contact form)...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5523-restoration-of-main-and-output-printed-circuit-boards-and-a-new-reservoir-capacitor/
